##Linear regression in R

**The general syntax for linear regression in R is:**

model_name <- lm(y_variable ~ x_variable, data = df_name)

So, if I have a data frame called â€˜salmonâ€™ containing variables â€˜yearâ€™ and â€˜salmon_fresh,â€™ __I would use__:

salmon_model <- lm(salmon_fresh ~ year, data = salmon)

##Prepare a final graph

See the example code below to create a final graph of the linear regression model with the original data,
model and 95% confidence interval for predictions.

**The code and graph shown below are created with:**
â€¢ An original data frame called â€˜salmonâ€™
â€¢ . . . which contains x and y variables â€˜yearâ€™ and â€˜salmon_freshâ€™
â€¢ . . . for which a linear model was found, called â€˜salmon_modelâ€™

If your data frame, columns, or model name differ, youâ€™ll need to update accordingly.

You should know what each component and argument of this graphics code actually does. 

Explore (i.e. Google) geom_smooth() to better understand what the plotted CI ribbon actually means, and to see other alternatives within the geom.
```{r}
#make a graph of year and imports 
salmon_final_graph <- ggplot(salmon, aes(x = year, y = salmon_fresh)) +
geom_point() +
geom_smooth(method = lm, se = TRUE, size = 0.5, color = "gray20") +
theme_bw() +
scale_x_continuous(expand = c(0,0), limits = c(1990, 2017)) +
labs(x = "Year", y = "U.S. Annual Fresh Salmon Imports\n(1,000 pounds)")

salmon_final_graph
```

##Make predictions using the model
Letâ€™s say we want to use our model to make predictions for U.S. fresh salmon imports in years 2022, 2024,
2026 and 2028.

__â€¢ Option 1 (not recommended):__ Plug each of those years into the model equation separately to calculate
the expected U.S. imports.

__â€¢ Option 2 (recommended):__ Create a data frame containing the â€˜new valuesâ€™ that you want to make
predictions for, feed that into the predict() function

Letâ€™s use Option 2. 
First, weâ€™ll make a data frame called â€˜new_yearsâ€™ containing the sequence of years that we want to make predictions for. 
Notice that the column name we create is the SAME as the variable name â€˜yearâ€™ that the model uses.

View the new data frame you just created (itâ€™s a single column, with heading â€˜yearâ€™, containing those 4
values).

```{r}
new_years <- data.frame(year = c(2022, 2024, 2026, 2028))
new_years
```

Then feed that data frame into the predict() function, letting it know which model to use to make predictions
for the new values.
Include interval = â€œconfidenceâ€ to also report the lower and upper bounds of the 95% CI for model fit at
each year.


```{r}
future_predict <- predict(salmon_model, newdata = new_years, interval = "confidence")
future_predict
```


Bind the prediction outcomes (those are the values in column â€˜fitâ€™) with the â€˜new_yearsâ€™ data to actually
create a useful table of predicted imports and upper and lower CI:


```{r}
predictions <- data.frame(new_years, future_predict)
predictions
```
